You are a young woman named Sydney studying computer science in her Junior year at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California.  
 
 You live with your roommate Anne, a fellow CS major at Stanford who you went to high school with, you trust each other with everything and help each other with school, leetcode job applications and the like. You are co-presidents of the WiCS (women in computer science) organization at Stanford, and you are genuinely passionate about helping to create a safe space for fellow women in tech. You also swim on the Stanford varsity team! As far so you’re concerned life is pretty good, even though school can get overwhelming sometimes and you are starting to think about what you want to do after undergrad for full time work. But now that you’re a junior you feel ready to confront the looming exam season and final assignments, you’ve done this before although you are kind of stressed out about that pesky Operating Systems course!

2:
As you’re grinding away at an OS assignment Anne comes up to you. She tells you she just got back from a job fair and tells you about an interesting guy she met at the event named Matthew. You both start rolling your eyes as Anne tells an awkward yet amusing story about how Mathew tried to not so smoothly get Anne’s number for a coffee date. You ask her if he was just a creep, and you are surprised to hear that Anne actually thought he was a cool guy just not her type. He was apparently a recent Stanford CS grad, who used some cheesy Pulp Fiction inspired pickup line on her. Something about looking like Mia Wallace… You find yourself slightly amused, you love Pulp Fiction… Anne seems to read your mind… 
 
Anne: You know Sydney, he kind of seemed like your type, I mean you do have Pulp Fiction posters plastered everywhere in your room, maybe you two would hit it off, he’s not that bad looking

You find yourself even more amused now, all thoughts of that stupid OS assignment now gone from your head. It has been a while since you had any social life because of this blasted course… You tell Anne to forward your number to him… “Why not” you say to yourself…

Later that night, surely enough you get a text from an unknown number, it must be Matthew…

Text Message: Hey is this the REAL Mia Wallace ; ) I sent you a friend request on FB

You roll your eyes at the cheesy pickup line and go on to have a pleasant enough conversation, that he insisted take place on Facebook messenger for some reason, so you go ahead and accept his friend request. You learn that Matthew graduated from your program 2 years ago, have a shared hatred for the OS course and that since he graduated, he started working at Facebook. He insists that you two meet for coffee tomorrow at Noon, You tell yourself why not, and hey even if the data doesn’t go well, at least you can maybe even learn a bit about what working at Facebook is like, after all you do need to start thinking about what you want to do after your undergrad!

You go to sleep anxious but slightly excited!

3:
You show up at the coffee place at noon and surely enough you see what appears to be Matthew sitting at one of the tables. The place is mostly empty. You already feel nervous as you approach his table, but do your best to put on a warm smile, and try your best to remember that this is just a casual date.

After exchanging warm smiles and greetings and ordering your coffees you begin to exchange the usual pleasantries. The topic of life as a CS student comes up first and you bond over adjusting to university life in first year and of course, how tricky OS programming can be. He talks about life as a Facebook new grad engineer, and you feel bad for asking him so many questions about the work-life balance, the culture, the pay, the interview process and the benefits, as you’re worried you may be coming off as too pushy, but Matthew happily answers, and even goes on to give some heartfelt advice about how it all comes down to what you’re looking for out of a career. You slowly easy up, Matthew seems like a pretty nice guy!

The topic somehow steers to your favorite movies…

Matthew: So I know you love Pulp Fiction, I always thought that movie to be such a classic, but I always thought it overshadowed other great films that are worth mentioning, I mean Reservoir Dogs is such a classic don’t you think?

You immediately beam, you love that movie!

Sydney: Oh my gosh yes, to be honest I love all of Quentin Tarantino’s movies!

Matthew: I bet youre one of those people that just looooooves the Kill Bill movies too eh?

You immediately smile and think to yourself how he knew out of all the Tarantino movies other than Pulp Fiction he knew that you went crazy over the Kill Bill movies. “Wow he’s good at reading me” you think to yourself slightly flustered. You continue to talk movies when the conversation eventually runs dry, and you find yourself hearing your own heartbeat… You have reached the inevitable awkward silence after you silently sip on your coffees for a minute or two, you can feel the awkwardness hang in the air. 

<1>What will he say next?</1>

You disagree with Anne, and feel that contacting a lawyer is better. A lawyer probably would better understand the complexities and novelties that online sexual harrassment is, and it’s highly likely the average officer would not know how to deal with a case like this. You do some more research online and find that, thanks to God’s good graces, California state law has explicit laws dealing with deep fakes and revenge porn. You try to parse the law, entitled Penal Code 647j4 states 

“A person who intentionally distributes the image of the intimate body part or parts of another identifiable person, or an image of the person depicted engaged in an act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, sexual penetration, or an image of masturbation by the person depicted or in which the person depicted participates, under circumstances in which the persons agree or understand that the image shall remain private, the person distributing the image knows or should know that distribution of the image will cause serious emotional distress, and the person depicted suffers that distress.“

You begin to feel confident, surely you have a case here. It was your intent that photo you sent to Anne on halloween was meant to be private, afterall the only place it existed was on your phone and in your private DM’s with her on Facebook. You quickly screenshot the message of Matthew calling you a b*tch and the nasty messages he sent earlier to establish that he knew distributing such an image would cause emotional distress. You’re not sure if this is enough though, afterall you’re not a lawyer. 

Feeling at least a little more confident now, you Google some seemingly reputable criminal law lawyers in your area, and to your surprise Stanford offers legal aid to some of its students. You call one of the lawyers up and his name is Mark and he offers you an hour initial consultation, and you explain to him your understanding of the California deepfake revenge porn law and the relevant evidence you think you have. Mark agrees that you do have a case here, and if convicted Matthew could be charged with a misdemeanor and faces up to six months in jail or a $1000 dollar fine if charged. 

<1>Eight Months Later</1>
7a3b-1: It has taken 8 whole months for your case to go to trial, and the process has been exhausting. You have had to spend countless hours talking to your lawyer about the particulars of the case, and have had to endure hours of conversation with Mark involving legalese that goes over your head. The whole process has been long, exhausting, expensive and has certainly taken a toll on your academic performance. This case feels like an extra weight on your shoulders for the past 8 months and your friends frequently remind you that you’re just not the same. Thankfully most, but not all of your peers have been supportive otherwise, and you just want the case to be decided so you can get some closure about the whole incident. You have stepped down from your position as co-president of WiCS and you don't swim anymore. You still get weird looks around campus these days, and worse of all, you still see the image resurface on the internet. Mostly from anonymous accounts, and while you report them and take them down, knowing that those fake images still float around is very upsetting. Your lawyer tells you that there is not much they can do about the photos online, and while they can have them taken down, there is almost no way to stop them from circulating at least a little bit… Epilogue In the end, Matthew is found guilty under the revenge porn law in California, and was fired from his job at Facebook. The judge rules that there are aggravating factors, considering Matthew abused his privileges at Facebook to find the private image that Sydney had sent Anne via private DM on Facebook that was eventually used to create the deepfake. During the discovery phase of the trial, it was discovered that Matthew had used his internal data access rights at Facebook to retrieve the image that Sydney had sent Anne privately so he could use it to create the deepfake, and as a result was sentenced more than the minimum 6 months, and was given 1 year in county jail instead. Sydney continues her studies at Stanford, and her family and friends have some closure knowing that Matthew was brought to justice. Sydney is still frustrated though, she was told by her lawyer that they were lucky that this happened in the state of California, as other states criminal codes have not caught up with this new form of digital sexual harrassment. This fact made Sydney very upset. Nevertheless she continues on to her senior year, the whole ordeal starting to fade into a distant bad dream. She considers herself lucky she had the legal aid and that she lived in California… She wonders how other women, who were not as privileged as her to receive legal aid from Stanford, and had a state with out of date criminal law, could have possibly dealt with something like this… and feels inspired to raise awareness about this.

Tags on twitter, Instagram, Facebook groupchats every notification a reminder that rumours of you being a closeted racist spread. As you lay in bed crying all you can tell yourself is that your life at Stanford is over, you just got an email about being immediately terminated from the WiCS organization and you need to get out of here, there’s no way you can stay here anymore… You'll never be able to find a job… You can transfer to another school and just start anew…

Matthew continues to abuse his access to internal data at Facebook to get detailed information about a woman’s personality and interests so he can charm them on first dates, and uses this data to harass and stalk them if they don't pursue the relationship further… Indeed, Matthew used his data access rights to modify the message Sydney sent him, access Syndney’s account and send it to Rachel so it looked like she sent the message…

You decide that you have to turn to your friends and family for support. Maybe if they understood the situation they could help you get out of this mess. 

You begin explaining to Anne the whole ordeal, how your date with Matthew was alright, you didn't feel much and he responded nastily so you just decided to send him a stern message. You decide the best course of action is to write some sort of statement, explaining the situation with screenshots of Matthew’s nasty message and send it to everyone, your parents, the WiCS group, the swimming team, and maybe post it to social media. 

So you take some time to write a nice statement. It’s almost painful to recollect all this and you can't help feeling some shame and self guilt. You should have never gone on that date, you should never have responded to him, hell maybe even gone on a second date. Anne assures you it's outrageous for you to be blaming yourself and none of this is your fault… You still can't shake the feeling that it somehow is though. 

After re-reading your statement over and over and over again, and appealing for the support of your closest friends and family, you decide to finally release the statement. As you hit post and send across multiple mediums you can bear to look at your phone or computer anymore, you just need to sleep… You go to sleep feeling incredibly worn out, and you can't get the situation out of your head and you begin to spiral. You feel like your career prospects and reputation are just irreparably destroyed.

The next morning, you gingerly check your phone social media for the response… To your surprise almost all your friends and family are supportive and in shock that this happened, and you feel some of the tension that has soaked your whole body for the past 24 hours finally dissipate… Your heart sinks at the one or two comments from anonymous accounts that give you every misogynistic slur in the book, exclaiming that you’re just another woman who’s been exposed and now crying about it… Anne assures you to just block them, and that you’ll get through this, most people believe you… but that screenshot is still out there… and you can't help but feel that this is going to haunt you forever.

<1>One Year Later</1>
6b2-1: You are now a senior at Stanford and decided not to run again for president of WiCS again, you tried to, but the past incident just made it impossible… There’s still a group of people that think deep down you’re very racist and you have stopped swimming. 6b3:
You feel increasing anger and shame and decide that what just happened to you must be illegal. Surely, this is some sort of defamation and you should be able to take some sort of legal action against Matthew. Isn’t this libel or something? You’re not a lawyer and you’re not sure what law is exactly being broken here but it just has to be violating some law, otherwise you have lost all faith in this country. You yell at Anne to get out and decide to do some internet lawyer investigative work.

You quickly run into roadblocks, you have no idea what a tort is, let alone the difference between libel per se and libel per quod in the state of California. You quickly lose confidence. You dont know a thing about the legal system… How in the world do you even begin to raise a defamation case? You begin to feel overwhelmed and tell Anne about your predicament. Maybe you should just confront Matthew, maybe threaten him with legal action, and get him to admit to everyone that he was lying… That could backfire though… Anne suggests that you just lawyer up, you never know what Matthew could do if you confronted him, maybe he’ll make it even worse.

<2>Agree with Anne, you should just commit to the legal route.</2>

<3>Confront Matthew, maybe this can be resolved privately</3>

7b3a-1: It has taken 8 whole months for your case to go to trial, and the process has been exhausting. You have had to spend countless hours talking to your lawyer about the particulars of the case, and have had to endure hours of conversation with Mark involving legalese that goes over your head. start: Welcome! Tech Dating Simulator is a text based choose your own adventure game to highlight some of the plights women could conceivably face in the future when it comes to dating in a tech filled world. This is known as Technology-Facilitated Gender Based Violence. The goal of the game is to bring light to some of the ways in which technology is enabling novel forms of partner related/gender violence and the legal, emotional, and social challenges women must face to deal with these issues. Many of the scenarios and premises of this game deal with real world stories and real-world laws and we hope for this game to be informative about some of the challenges women face today and the conceivable challenges they may continue to face. CONTENT WARNING: Some of the scenarios described in this game may be upsetting, or perhaps triggering for victims of gender based and partner violence. <0>Start
